<font face="Lucida Grande">Click Next to begin the survey.</font>

Welcome!

Welcome to the Patient Preferences to Prevent Neonatal Herpes Survey.


Thank you for your participation!
When you're ready to start, click Next (the right arrow) to begin!

Objectives

  • This presentation will give you information about herpes in adults and newborn babies.


  • One way to prevent herpes in newborn babies is to have a Cesarean delivery.


  • You will learn how herpes can affect a baby and how Cesarean delivery can affect you.


  • At the end of this presentation, you will be asked your preferences about several ways to prevent neonatal herpes.
<font face="Lucida Grande">When you're ready to start, click next to begin!</font>
<font face="Lucida Grande"><font size="+7">Before we get started, we need a little information about you.</font></font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">To continue, click Next (the right arrow) to begin!</font>
How old are you?
What type of provider do you see for your pregnancy?
How many live births have you had?
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
Have you had a Cesarean delivery in the past?
If you could choose a method of delivery for your baby, would it be:
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
Do you have genital herpes?
Have you had a blood test for herpes in this pregnancy?
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
What was the result of your blood test for herpes?
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
What is your marital status?
Which best describes your race/ethnicity?
What is your annual household income?
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
Has your prenatal provider discussed herpes with you?
Do you know anyone who had a baby with neonatal herpes?
Does your partner have genital herpes?

Thank you for your responses. Now, we'll tell you a little more about herpes.

What is Herpes?

Herpes is caused by a virus - herpes simplex virus (HSV). There are two main types:

HSV-1 (usually causes oral herpes)
  • Is also called herpes simplex virus type-1
  • Usually infects people in childhood
  • Causes "cold sores" or "fever blisters" on or near the lips
  • Can be transmitted to sex partner's genitals during oral sex

HSV-2 (usually causes genital herpes)
  • Is also called herpes simplex virus type-2
  • Causes sores on or near the genitals, anus, or buttocks
  • Can be transmitted to sex partner's genitals or anus
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

How Common is Herpes?


• About 1 in 4 pregnant women
test positive for HSV-2, the
commonest cause of genital herpes.

• The box to the right shows 100 squares.
Yellow squares show the number of
women who test positive for HSV-2.

• Up to 90% of pregnant women with
genital herpes do not know that they
have herpes.

const.name: textCaption
const.value: About 1 in 4 pregnant women test positive for HSV-2.

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

How Do You Get Genital Herpes?



  • You can get genital herpes from sexual contact with somebody who has herpes on his genitals or mouth.

  • You can get genital herpes even when your partner does not have sores or does not know that he has herpes.

  • 2% of women get genital herpes during their pregnancies.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Genital Herpes May Look Like This:














Or, there may be NO symptoms or sores.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

How Can Genital Herpes Hurt Your Baby?



In pregnancy, genital herpes is important because the virus can infect the baby during vaginal delivery.


If the baby contacts the herpes virus as she passes through the birth canal at delivery, the baby could become infected.


Neonatal herpes might make your baby very sick and possibly cause death or complications like cerebral palsy.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

If Your Baby Gets Neonatal Herpes, How Sick Will He or She Be?

Your baby would need to stay in the hospital for blood tests, spinal tap and intravenous medication for about 3 weeks.
With treatment:
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

const.name: textCaption
const.value: 50% of babies do well and are normal.

module.const: Examples of Babies with Neonatal Herpes
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Summary of Herpes

  • About 25% of pregnant women have genital herpes.
  • About 2% of women get herpes while pregnant.
  • Most people with herpes do not know that they have herpes.
  • It is possible to give your baby herpes at the time of delivery if you have genital herpes.
  • Babies with herpes need immediate hospitalization and treatment.
  • Even with treatment, the baby may have long term problems or die.

const.name: textCaption
const.value: About 25% of women have genital herpes.

const.name: textCaption
const.value: About 2% of women get herpes while pregnant.

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What is Recommended to Prevent Neonatal Herpes?




  • Currently, one method to prevent neonatal herpes is Cesarean delivery for women with genital sores at the time of labor.

  • In the next section, you will learn about Cesarean delivery.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What is a Cesarean Delivery?



  • It is delivery of the baby through an incision in the abdomen.
  • It is the most common surgery performed in the United States.
  • About 22% of all deliveries in the United States are by Cesarean.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>
For Cesarean delivery, first an incision is made on the skin. Usually the incision is horizontal, along the bikini line.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>
Then, an incision is made on the uterus and the baby is delivered.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What are the Risks of Cesarean Delivery?


The baby:
  • may have short term respiratory problems.

You:
  • Would have longer recovery time than vaginal delivery. You would spend 3 days in hospital instead of 1 day.
  • Would need narcotic pain medications.
  • Would need to have 6 weeks of decreased activity.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>
What are the Complications of Cesarean Delivery?

• Possible infection of uterus or skin. The risk is up to 15% (150 in 1000). Treatment is intravenous antibiotics.


  • Possible blood loss causing anemia. The risk is 1% (10 in 1000), and treatment will require a blood transfusion.


  • Possible blood clots in your lungs. The risk is 0.7% (7 in 1000).


  • Possible injury to internal organs. The risk is 0.1% (1 in 1000).
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What Are the Long-Term Effects of Cesarean Delivery?


  • You are more likely to have a Cesarean delivery in your next pregnancy.
  • You would have a 1% chance of uterine rupture during labor in your next pregnancy.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

What are the Benefits of Cesarean Delivery?

  • No episiotomy or vaginal tear.
  • May be less likely to have leakage of urine with cough or sneeze than with vaginal delivery.
  • Decreases (but does not completely eliminate) the risk of neonatal herpes in women with genital herpes sores at the time of labor.
  • A woman who has had one Cesarean delivery can still try to have a vaginal delivery with the next pregnancy.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

To Review

  • Neonatal herpes can occur if the herpes virus is in the birth canal at the time of vaginal delivery.
  • Neonatal herpes is rare but can cause death or long term problems for the baby.
  • One way to prevent neonatal herpes is Cesarean delivery for women with genital sores at the time of labor.
  • Cesarean delivery has some risks to the mother and may not always prevent neonatal herpes.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Risk Visualizer Training

This tool is designed to help you understand and appreciate small risks. Imagine you are in a stadium with 10,000 people. A few of the people have a special ticket. The binoculars allow you to look around the stadium and see the people who have the special ticket. These people are shown in red. Imagine that 10 of the 10,000 (0.1%) people in the stadium got the special ticket. Take a look around and see what this looks like. After you've done that, let's change the percentage of people who have the tickets and see what this looks like. Click the plus button a few times until 800 of 10,000 people have special tickets (8%). Now take a look around and see what this looks like.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>

Your Preferences: Cesarean to Prevent Neonatal HSV

Suppose that you have genital herpes sores at the time of labor.
What risk of neonatal herpes would make you choose a Cesarean delivery?

Instructions: If there are 10,000 pregnant women with genital herpes sores in labor in this stadium, and all of them delivered their babies vaginally, the number of faces in red will have babies with neonatal herpes. Choose the risk level at which you would rather have a Cesarean delivery than risk having a baby with neonatal herpes by using the plus and minus arrows.

What Is The Chance That You Will Have A Baby With Neonatal Herpes?

That depends on if you have genital herpes or if you get herpes while you are pregnant. It is much more common for women who first get herpes during pregnancy to infect their babies.

  • Women who get newly infected with genital herpes at the end of pregnancy have about a 50% chance of infecting the baby.
  • Women who have been infected with genital herpes before pregnancy, or early in pregnancy, have about a 1% chance of infecting the baby at delivery.

The most reliable way to know if you have herpes, or if you are at risk to get herpes from your partner, is to have a blood test.
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click next arrow to continue.</font>
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Your Preferences: Blood Test to Detect Herpes

An accurate blood test for herpes exists. Please select a response to the following statements:
<font face="Lucida Grande" size="+5">I would want <u>my blood tested</u> to see if I have herpes as part of my routine prenatal care. </font>
<font face="Lucida Grande" size="+5">I would want <u>my partner's blood tested</u> to see if he has herpes. </font>

const.name: questionStart
const.value: Would you be willing to pay

const.name: questionEnd
const.value: for a herpes blood test for YOURSELF?

const.name: questionStart
const.value: Would you be willing to pay

const.name: questionEnd
const.value: for a herpes blood test for YOUR PARTNER?

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Your Preferences: Anti-herpes medication in pregnancy
Suppose that you are tested for HSV and find out that you are infected with genital herpes.
The chance that you would infect your baby at the time of delivery is about 2 in 10,000 (0.02%).
A medication exists (such as acyclovir) that we think is safe in late pregnancy and lowers the chance that you would need a Cesarean for genital sores at the time of labor. It also might lower the chance that the baby gets herpes. The medication is taken by mouth for the last month of pregnancy.

Please indicate whether you agree or disagree with the following statement:

I would want to take this medication for the last month of my pregancy.

const.name: questionStart
const.value: Would you be willing to pay

const.name: questionEnd
const.value: for a month's supply of the medication?

module.const: <font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Your Preferences: Rapid Test to Detect Herpes in Labor

An accurate test to detect herpes virus in the birth canal at the time of labor is available.
The test requires a swab of your vagina.
If the test reports that herpes in the birth canal you may be more likely to have a Cesarean delivery.
If offered, I would want my birth canal checked for herpes virus at the time of labor:
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
Your Preferences: Cesarean Delivery to Prevent Neonatal Herpes

Suppose that herpes is found in your birth canal while you are in labor.
There is about a 1-3% chance that the baby will get herpes if delivered vaginally.
In this situation, would you proceed with vaginal delivery or would you prefer Cesarean delivery to lower the chance that the baby gets herpes?
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>
Your Preferences: Cesarean Delivery to Prevent Neonatal Herpes

Now, suppose that there is a 50% (50/100) chance that the baby will get herpes if delivered vaginally.

In this case, would you proceed with vaginal delivery or would you prefer a Cesarean delivery?
<font face="Lucida Grande">Click the next arrow to continue.</font>

Great job. Now, we have three quick questions about this presentation. Please choose a response to the following statements:


I found the information in the presentation was helpful.
I would recommend this presentation to my friends to learn more about herpes in pregnancy.
I found the presentation increased my anxiety about my pregnancy.

Thank you for your participation!



If you have questions or concerns regarding neonatal herpes, please contact the study coordinator or ask your prenatal provider.



This concludes the survey. You may now safely exit this window.
<font face="Lucida Grande"></font>
